awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Forest Water Use and the Influence of Acid Deposition
awd_abstract_narration:
Forests sequester carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and take up water from soils, thus regulating the flow of water in streams. Some evidence suggests that the balance among these processes may have been fundamentally altered by high acid deposition ("acid rain") in the eastern United States during the post-Industrial Revolution period.  During this period it is hypothesized that acid deposition decreased nutrients in the soil such as calcium, magnesium and potassium. This may have required trees to pump more water from the soil through their systems to obtain an adequate supply of nutrients, causing a subsequent loss of water flowing in streams.  With the decline in acid deposition over the last 20-30 years, forests soils are able to retain more nutrients. This may reduce the amount of water that trees need to pump through their systems. Thus while maintaining the same rate of growth, trees may release less water to the atmosphere, improving their water use efficiency and leaving more water to feed into streams. This hypothesized response of forests to changing levels of acid deposition is not currently considered in the land surface components of global climate models. Since carbon dioxide and water vapor are the two most important greenhouse gases, it is vital to accurately model their land-atmosphere exchange. 

The proposed research uses a catchment-based approach to investigate the effects of changing acid deposition on forest water use efficiency. Tree ring carbon isotopes will be used to reconstruct historical forest water use efficiency time series within six catchments that have been differentially impacted by acid deposition due to distinctions between their underlying bedrock mineralogy and geological histories. The research will also capitalize on experimental treatments that have altered soil biogeochemistry in paired catchment designs (Bear Brook, ME; Hubbard Brook, NH; and Fernow Experimental Forest, WV). Stream discharge analysis and model-based approaches will be applied to detect the impact of acid deposition on forest water use efficiency and streamflow. 

The project will support a Ph.D. student, who will receive training in a wide range of field, laboratory, and modeling techniques, and at least eight undergraduate students. High school students will also be involved through established programs, and will participate in both field and lab activities. All senior members of the project team have track records of recruiting students from underrepresented groups. Results will be communicated to the broader scientific community through journal publications and conference presentations, and a special conference session will be organized with an objective of sharing research findings with the modeling community.

por.por_cntn:
This project tested the hypothesis that historical trends in acid rain, through its influence on soil base cation availability, has altered the amount of water used by forests in the eastern United States. This effect had been suggested by plot- and plant-level studies that linked lower base cation availability with reduced water use efficiency (WUE, the amount of carbon gained by plants per unit water lost via transpiration). Analyses of river and streamflow statistics did not detect this effect on a widespread basis, but evidence in support of the hypothesis was documented in a paired watershed experiment in which one watershed was subjected to several decades of enhanced acidic deposition. Analyses of carbon isotopes in tree rings, which record historical variations in tree WUE, shed some light on these mixed findings. Cores were collected from over 500 trees within eastern U.S. watersheds, spanning gradients in both soil base cation availability and sulfate adsorption capacity. The historical WUE values inferred from these cores were highly species specific, with more variation seen from species to species than within species across soil types or experimental treatments. In general, coniferous species exhibited WUE trends that were more consistent with trends in atmospheric deposition, while broadleaf deciduous species exhibited WUE trends that were more consistent with rising atmospheric carbon dioxide levels. The mixed composition of eastern U.S. forests potentially diminished the effects of changing acidic deposition on forest WUE and the streamflow that emerges from the forested watersheds. As part of this research, a new technique was introduced to infer forest WUE from eddy covariance measurements, which are collected over forested ecosystems throughout the world.

            At the University of Virginia (UVa), this project supported one Ph.D. student and involved the participation of six undergraduate students, three of whom has summer research positions and one of whom completed a Distinguished Majors Program thesis. Three of these undergraduate students went on to graduate programs in the environmental sciences at Colorado School of Mines, Oregon State University, and UC-Santa Barbara. The project hosted a Forest Water Use symposium at UVa, which was attended by all the principle investigators from the collaborative research project, graduate and undergraduate students from the participating universities, as well as scientists from the U.S. Forest Service and outside universities. Project personnel also organized and chaired a special session on ?Examining Transpiration and Photosynthesis from Ecosystem to Global Scales: Observations, Linkages, and Drivers? at the American Geophysical Union 2018 Fall Meeting. Field work in Shenandoah National Park, Virginia, was conducted with the participation of six high school students from the Environmental Sciences Academy at Western Albemarle High School, who spent full days with the project team collecting soil samples and tree cores. Findings from the research have been disseminated in scientific journal articles, presentations at scientific meetings, and in local media outlets. This research has introduced the concept that soil base cation status can potentially regulate forest water use and streamflow, which has implications for water resources modeling and management.
